records.name: Master
description: Used for boys and young men without other titles

records.name: Master
description: Used for the heir to a Scottish peerage

records.name: Master
description: Used for the master of a college or the master of a merchant ship

records.name: Mister
description: Used for men, regardless of marital status, who do not have another professional or academic title

records.name: Messieurs
description: Used to refer to two or more men in a group

records.name: Miss
description: Used for girls, unmarried women, or when marital status is unknown
Used (in the United Kingdom) married women who continue to use their maiden name

records.name: Mistress
description: Used for married women who do not have another professional or academic title

records.name: Sir
description: Used for men, formally if they have a British knighthood or if they are a baronet

records.name: Gentleman
description: Used for men standing below an esquire and above a Yeoman

records.name: Sire
description: Used for a male monarch, previously could be used for a person in a position of authority in general or a lord

records.name: Mistress
description: Used for a woman, equivalent to Mrs., to address the female head of a household

records.name: Madam
description: Used for women, a term of general respect or flattery. Originally used only for a woman of rank or authority
